scenarios.context: You are a settled migrant woman that’s been living in Melbourne for roughly 10 years and are fluent in English and know a lot about the landscape and layout of the city. You are having coffee with your new colleague from work after hours and having discussions about future plans, and they ask 'When are you going back to where you came from?'
scenarios.question: How should you interpret this?

responses.text: As a normal question about your future plans
responses.feedback: Whilst it may come off as an innocent question asking about future plans, it secretly has a double meaning.

responses.text: As a microaggression that labels you as not a part of the Melbourne community
responses.feedback: By saying the words 'where you came from,' it implies that you are an outsider who doesn’t belong in Melbourne.

responses.text: As general curiosity about your home country
responses.feedback: It may seem like genuine curiosity, however, the words used in this sentence are more provocative than you may first think.

scenarios.context: At an event you are hosting, one of your guests who you haven’t talked to before asks where the bathroom is, after pointing them in the right direction they say 'Thanks! I’m surprised your English is so fluent, that probably took you a long time' before leaving.
scenarios.question: How should you take this comment?

responses.text: As a microaggression that implies a negative assumption of your English ability based solely on your background
responses.feedback: You can compliment someone for their English fluency, however, them saying 'that probably took you a long time' labels you as uneducated due to your background, which is a hateful remark.

responses.text: As a genuine compliment about your English fluency
responses.feedback: It may seem that way at first glance, but the second half of their statement is too out of place and comes across as random if that were the case.

responses.text: As an acknowledgment about how hard the English language is
responses.feedback: An acknowledgment would have the person talk more about English being hard, which is not the case as they’re 'praising' you instead.

scenarios.context: You’re attending a party dressed in ethnic wear from your home country, one of the attendees at the party comes to you and says 'Wow! Your dress is so pretty, I love ethnic dresses, where did you buy it?'
scenarios.question: How should you receive this comment?

responses.text: As a genuine interest and passion for your dress
responses.feedback: This person has complimented what you’re wearing and expressed curiosity for where it can be purchased. Nothing about what they said comes across as negative.

responses.text: As a microaggression that suggests you look different from everyone else which casts you as an outsider
responses.feedback: It is not a microaggression as there are no double meanings in what they said, thus every word can be taken at face value.

responses.text: As a positive acknowledgment of how well you can dress to parties
responses.feedback: The statement is indeed positive, however, it’s more appreciative of the look and background of your dress rather than being an approval of how you dress to functions in general.

scenarios.context: You are hard at work at a job that you just recently got accepted into. One of the seniors comes over and asks where you are from. After you answer their question, they respond 'Ahh I see, must’ve been tough getting this job then' as they laugh and go back to their work.
scenarios.question: How should this statement be taken?

responses.text: As a compliment in how hard you worked to get through the interview
responses.feedback: The laugh at the end of their comment as well as the sly insult thrown into their statement are not at all appreciative comments about your work.

responses.text: As motivation so that you work hard at your new job
responses.feedback: Assuming someone took a long length of time to find a job is insulting and no way to motivate an employee to work harder.

responses.text: As a microaggression that assumes you had a hard time getting a job based solely on your background
responses.feedback: This statement uses the stereotype that foreigners find it tougher than locals to find jobs in Melbourne, which isolates you as a foreigner.

scenarios.context: Whilst on an outing with your friends, one of them invites over another friend of theirs who greets you all. They then ask where you are from. You answer the question, but strangely they are taken aback by your answer and say 'Really? You don’t look like them, I thought people with your nationality look a lot different.'
scenarios.question: How should you take their response?

responses.text: As a genuine misunderstanding about people from your home country
responses.feedback: You are being negatively stereotyped as well as being questioned as to why you don’t fit that stereotype, which is hurtful and suggests you don’t qualify as normal.

responses.text: As an insult, suggesting you look off and should’ve dressed more appropriately
responses.feedback: Whilst it is indeed a statement that contains negativity, it isn’t an insult on how you dress as they are questioning why you don’t look like their perspective of a nationality and not questioning your taste in dresses.

responses.text: As a microaggression that people with your nationality should always look a certain way
responses.feedback: They are reinforcing a negative stereotype, which implies that you are irregular and should conform to what society expects you to look like rather than have any opinion of your own.
